Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Omnia in duos: Duo in Unum: Unus in Nihil: Haec nec Quattuor nec Omnia nec Duo nec Unus nec Nihil Sunt.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Come on, candles, out!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: In Volunta Divina et Verbum Magi: Lux! Exstinguat!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Vide, Magister. There's something wrong.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What's the matter? What's happened?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: I've just seen something. Something of consequence to you.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: To me?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Yes. My own death.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Perhaps we had better hasten your training.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Have you mastered the threefold transmutation?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: You have?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Well, almost.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: It's very difficult. Have you committed to memory undying the Codex de Profundis?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: The first two chapters.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: It's long. And what about the Ritual of Banishment as prescribed by my late master Balisarius?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: To tell the truth, I haven't dared try it. What's the point, anyway?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: The point? The point is you don't know it, and you're no magician without it. It was my hope to school you, to mold your faculties and wits... I still believe you have some talent. Somewhere.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I hate books. I hate drill. I want a real task.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: There's no time now. When I'm gone, half the powers in the universe will vanish with me. And what's the use of a few lingering skills if they're left in the hands of a child?  Listen!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I don't hear anything.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Here, wear this.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Voices, singing on the road.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I don't see anything.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: We have visitors!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Looks forbidding enough, don't you think?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Here are your sticks.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: No -- they'll think me infirm. You know, Balisarius wore this whenever he changed lead into gold. He could really do that, you know. I never could. Too bad -- you'd stand to inherit some real wealth.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: You're in a morbid frame of mind. What's all this about dying? You don't even look sick.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs to me.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a handful of that sulphurous ash over there...

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Nunc habeus lux!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Et calor!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Welcome to Cragganmore. I am Ulrich. Which one of you calls himself Valerian?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: That would be me. We are here on behalf...

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: I know why you're here. You're a delegation from Urland, from beyond Dalvatia. Let's see the artifacts.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: A bone. Scorched. A rock, fire- blackened.  Scales.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: All right. How did you come by these?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I found them. At the mouth of the lair.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: What else?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: A claw.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: That's no claw. It's a tooth. By the gods!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: And you want me to do battle with that?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Who else can we turn to? We all know what we're dealing with here. This is a basilicok.  This is no stag, no bear, no natural creature. This is one of your kind. And only a necromancer such as yourself can rid us of it.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Did you try the Meredydd sisters? What about Rinbod? I've heard it said he killed a dragon once.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: They're all dead. You're the only one left.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: It's a long way to Urland.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Every quarter, upon the solstices and the equinoxes there's a new victim.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: My daughter, for one.

Speaker: other travelers
Dialogue: My sister... cousins...

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: All women?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Girls. Virgins, to be exact, chosen by lot.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Master, don't you think --

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Silence!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Are you afraid of dragons?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: No. Sorcerers and dragons go back a long long time together. If it weren't for sorcerers, there wouldn't be any dragons.  All right. I'll go.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: I know of this dragon. Vermithrax Pejorative: she's four hundred years old. As far as I can tell she's the last of her kind. Very appropriate that I'm the one to finish her off, don't you think?  You, Hodge.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: While I'm gone see you keep your nose in your books and your hands out of my reagents. Leave my instruments alone too.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Look at yourself. How far will you get like that? A league, two leagues?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: I'm not worried about the road.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Why don't you wave your hands around and summon up a coach-and-four?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Don't mock me.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: You pilgrims: You're used to lotteries. Why not draw straws to see who'll be first to carry ironshanks here.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Hold your tongue. If the master's got a mind to go, he'll go.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Send me. You're always saying I need seasoning. I need a test. Let me go.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: You're not ready.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I'm ready for anything.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Don't be so hasty. Your time will come.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Tyrian!?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Good morning, all.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: We're not afraid of you. Give us the road.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Why, the road is yours. All the way to Urland. It's a long journey, isn't it? But when you're in search of a sorcerer, I suppose no distance is too great.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Say nothing.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: What do you want with us?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Well, like my good friends here, I've come for a bit of black magic. No doubt you've heard of our troubles at home. This is Cragganmore, is it not?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Aye, this be the place of Ulrich.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: And here we have the mystical presence himself, no?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: You'd best keep your distance -- and your manners.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: If he's ready to lay a dragon in its grave, he's got nothing to fear from me.  I've no more love for that creature than you lot. Nor has the King. But, before you stir things up, don't you think it a good idea to see you've got the right man for the job?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Aha -- it's a test you're looking for. We don't do tests.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: I'm sure you don't. They never do tests -- and not many real deeds either. Oh, conversation with your grandmother's shade in a darkened room, the odd love potion or two... but comes a doubter, well then, it's the wrong day, the planets are not aligned, the entrails aren't favorable, we don't do tests.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: We've got no doubts. We require no test.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: And you're not going to get one.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Go to the conjuring room. The iron box. Fetch me the dagger within.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: The dagger. Be quick.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: You shall have your test.

Speaker: ulrich's voice
Dialogue: Where are you, boy? I'm waiting.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Not this one, was it?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: The very one. Let it fall.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Vita regula, vita hieratica!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Go on. Don't worry, you can't hurt me.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Hodge -- what are you doing?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Just making my farewell, thank you very much.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Be careful with that! You don't know what you're doing.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Stand back!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Cragganmore! Domus non i am! Silva celet!

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Oh, it's a vale of tears in which we dwell. It doesn't matter who you are, a king in his robes, a peasant in his rags, when your time comes, no magic can save you...

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I guess...

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: ...the kindest lord a man could ask for... now he's gone. Ye gods he was fussy about his bath. And you'd think he could boil his own eggs with the snap of a finger, but no, he had old Hodge do it, of course.  I'm going to miss him.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Me too...

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: No you don't. All you care about is the tricks and knavery. Well, you don't pull any wool over these old eyes. It'll be a mighty long walk before you fill his shoes, you mark my word.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What's the matter, Hodge, pack too heavy? Here.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Careful with that!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Too cold, is it?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Stop it!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Too warm?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Stop it, I say! Out of respect for the master!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I've got as much respect for the master as anyone, old man. But -- then again, I'm master now.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: I left my farm with seeds unplanted, calves unborn, nothing but a wife to chase down the strays, and for what? A funeral, that's what.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Because some people said, find a magician. Not just a local fellow, an import, a good forty leagues from home. An all-powerful necromancer. Ha -- some necromancer!

Speaker: malkin
Dialogue: Hold your tongue, Greil. Sit. Eat.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: I'll not sit. I'll not eat. See you the Great Bear. His tail points east. It's the equinox. Have you forgotten? Or rather not think about it?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: He's right. I brought us here for nothing. May the gods help whoever's daughter it is tonight.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Good morrow, good morrow. Peace be with you.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Easy now. We mean no harm. We've been looking for you.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Well, you've found us.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: More the other way around, I'd say.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: A few words, that's all. You were looking for a conjurer.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: He's dead.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Right. Requiscat in pace.  Ecce: magister novus!

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: How say you?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: My lord Ulrich is no longer. All that you asked of him, you may now expect of me. The dangers he would face, I will now conquer. The task he would undertake I will now fulfill. I am Galen Bradwardyn, inheritor of Ulrich's craft and knowledge, and I am the Sorcerer you seek.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Well, that's a handsome thought, O wizard of wizards. But if there's one thing our friend Tyrian has shown us, it's to beware the pig in the poke. Who's got a dagger?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: No tests!!

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Call it proof, then.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: We've seen enough tests.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Well I haven't. All I've seen is death. Death in our families, death on the road, and tonight, death at home.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: What's come over you, anyway? Have you lost your wits?

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: I don't like it. Young snot-nose comes in here for sport at our expense. We're on a fool's errand, but we don't have to listen to this. I don't want to hear any more about sorcery. I don't want to hear any more about spells.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You must be hungry.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What's the matter with him?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: It's not just him. It's all of us. It's the equinox.

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: Close enough! Bring her out!

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: Now be it known throughout the kingdom, that this maiden, having lawfully been chosen by a deed of fortune and destiny, shall hereby give up her life for the greater good of Urland.

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: By this act shall be satisfied the powers that dwell underground and the spirits that attend thereto. In gratitude for this sacrifice His Majesty has declared the family -- what's the name? --

Speaker: retainer
Dialogue: Plowman! The family Plowman!

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: -- the family Plowman to be free of obligations, taxations, levys and imposts for a period not to exceed five years...

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: -- ordained and signed this day, etc., Casiodorus, in his glory the reigning king of this our realm... his seal, his mark, duly read by Chancellor Horsrik in his holy name.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: There. I see them.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Who's that old man?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Where? Which one?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: That one. That's the man from Cragganmore. Now what's he doing here?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Filling in for the chief, I reckon.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: What a pity.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What have you got there?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: None of your business.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: A little gold, eh? What do you say I change it into lead?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Save your jokes for someone else. Me, I don't care for braggarts.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: And I don't care for frauds.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I'm no fraud.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Call it fool then. Upstart. Whatever pleases you.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Hodge, nobody forced you to come along.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Oh, I'm here of my own free will, all right. We each do the master's bidding in our own way.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Well, if he told you I needed wetnursing, why don't you just turn yourself around and go back home.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Home, is it? You've seen to that, haven't you? Gone to seed, I'd say...

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: You're too far behind us. Come on out.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You go ahead, I'll catch up.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Not a good idea to get separated. Let's go.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Right. I'll be along.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: That's all right. Don't come in.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You better get back to the group, they're probably worried.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I prefer to swim alone, if you don't mind.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: By the gods!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Stay away.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I suppose you'll tell everyone. Go ahead, I don't care. It's a relief.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I'm not going to say anything.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I don't blame you. I was stupid. Careless. A silly woman!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Take it easy. I knew the moment I saw you. I've known the whole time.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You never knew a thing. No one knew. Not since I was born. Go on, run off and tell them. It'll make a great story.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Don't worry. No one's going to find out. Just tell me: why?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Ask my father.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: The lottery! Daughters are chosen, but sons are not!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: That's right. Unless you have plenty of gold or property.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: If you're rich enough, your name never goes in.  My father is poor. So are a lot of fathers.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Hodge!

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Galen? Can you hear me?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I hear you.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: You know, somebody shot me, but I can still talk. There's something that has to be done.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Not that cockatrice. Ulrich's ashes. Here.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: Take it. Sorry, you'll have to peel it loose.

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: ...burning water... find the lake, throw it in...

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What are you doing with this, Hodge?

Speaker: hodge
Dialogue: ...burning water...

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Hodge, don't die. Listen to me. You're not going to die.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam!  Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam!

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Urland!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Come on. Don't dawdle here.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: The whole kingdom like this?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: No. We're near the lair. Keep moving.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Over there. Doesn't matter. We're in no danger if we just pass through quickly.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I see it. Let's have a look.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Greil! Malkin! Help!

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Look, you don't have to do this. We know you're a fine young magician. None better. There's no need to prove it to us.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Are there other entrances?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: No. One's enough.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Come on. The road's this way. We'll tell everybody how close you got.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No smoke. How do you know it's in there?

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Don't be a fool. Come away now and live to tell about it.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Go ahead! You're going to die! What a fine trick that will be!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Now, great mountain, hear my command: Terrae lapsus consignet latibulum draconis! Evanescat latibulum draconis!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Father? Hello?

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: Now are you cleansed of your sins! Now are you born again, purified in spirit, into the fellowship of Jesus Christ!

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Welcome back, my son.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Father, what are you doing? Have you all lost your minds?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Some have.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: It's this monk. He can read and write, and talk too, I'm afraid.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: And they listen?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Shh! They think this a holy place, a tabernacle.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: This is the granary. What kind of welcome is this? I've got news of the sorcerer and news of the dragon.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: You were brave to go, you and your friends. But nobody cares. Listen -- he knows what they want to hear.

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: The man who walks with Christ is not a man to fear a dragon: Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death I will fear no evil! You say you are preyed upon by a foul beast. Yes, but what is the nature of this beast? It comes to you on bat's wings and clawed feet, does it not? It breathes fire, does it not? And it lives under ground. This is no dragon. This is Lucifer!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Whoever it is, he's dead.

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: Nay, brother! It is not as easy as that. Allegiance to Christ, to be sure, but also prayer and confession. These are the arms by which Satan may be put down.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: You're talking about superstition, friend. None of that has anything to do with what I, Galen, have already achieved.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: You brought this stranger?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Ulrich's apprentice. He's a braggart, but it doesn't matter.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: People of Urland! Send a messenger to the king. Vermithrax is dead. Crushed by the power of the moon and the stars! Laid low by ancient wisdom. Dropped into the Abyss by mystical practice.

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: Spoken like a pagan. Every word as reprobate as it is false!  Solum in hoc signo vinces!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Nihil plus mysterium!

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: Praise God! Blessed is he that is humble before the Lord!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Your god had nothing to do with it.

Speaker: malkin
Dialogue: We saw it with our own eyes. He flew to the mountain top. He was a bird. He brought forth lightning. I saw it.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Put that away. What if you were seen?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I'm going to be seen. I want to be seen. Tonight the world finds out that you never had a son.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: No, you mustn't do that. It's too soon. We've got to think about this, we've got to make a plan.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Father: the danger is over.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I know. What am I going to say to my friends who still mourn for their lost girls.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You'll say you did what you had to. This is a time for celebration -- and forgiveness.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Looks like you've been up to a little sorcery yourself.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Or is it witchcraft?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What's the matter? A real woman never stops talking.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I think it was much easier being a boy.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: The damnedest thing is, she was twice the man of anyone else in the village. Now she's twice the woman.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Would that I had been as clever as her father.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Come now, Greil. Don't begrudge a life spared.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: I begrudge nothing. But I wonder at what we have seen and how it was done.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: You were there.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: I saw what I saw. But this jack-anapes was barely ready to carry his master's chamberpot. Isn't it strange that at the very moment the beast is put down we should have a holy man here in the village?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: You don't believe that superstitious Christian rot, do you?

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: It is said God works his wonders in mysterious ways.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: A celebration! Don't stop on my account. You -- musicians, more music!

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: A toast! To the deed of the day! You see, good news travels fast. The King himself has already heard it. And like yourselves, tonight he's overcome with joy.

Speaker: malkin
Dialogue: What would you have of us then?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Not a thing. It's this one.  The King would meet our new benefactor and offer his gratitude to the man who succeeded where so many have failed.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What sort of gratitude? A knife in the belly? An arrow in the back?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: My young friend, I'd as soon dispatch you as I did the others, and for the same reason. But his Majesty would like a cozy chat, and commands otherwise.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Don't go, Galen. Cast a spell and turn them into toads. It should be easy; that's what they are.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Well, well: still plenty of cheek under those skirts, it seems.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Don't worry. I'll be back.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: One of the best things about the water here in Urland is that there's so much of it -- look at that!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Mmm. Good. But not cold enough. Perhaps I could borrow a scarf from his Majesty.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I cover the goblet, so... remove, so... and behold: winter in a mug!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: All right. How many of you have ever seen a table fly?

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Enough! That's fine.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Wait, it'll rise now.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Don't bother. Not necessary.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Tell me: the landslide -- it was accomplished this same way?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: I see. And having rendered such unique service to our kingdom, what would you claim as a reward?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Please -- no payment. I have always found magical practice to be its own reward. I seek only some yet greater challenge.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Did you ever hear of King Gaiseric? Of course not, you weren't even born. He was my brother, a great King and a valiant man-at-arms. When he ascended to the throne, the dragon was unbridled. No one knew where it might strike next. So he brought forth his broadsword and his spear, assembled a company of his best fighters and went out to do battle.  He was never seen again. But his attack provoked the most terrible reprisals: whole villages incinerated, entire crops burned. Death, famine, horrible.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: How did you arrogate to yourself the role of savior?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I was invited.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Not by me. Did you ever consider the consequences of failure?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What failure? What's the matter with you people? You want the dragon back?

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Then the beast is dead?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Yes, of course. Dead.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: We shall see.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Cubiculum gravis aperat!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Open up, dammit! Fenestra gravis aperat! Asser gravis aperat! Divinitus!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Salve, magistrum iuvenilum.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: I've studied Latin. Greek, too. Me appelo Elspeth, filia regis.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: How do you do.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Please don't think ill of us. My father is a wonderful man, a wise man. The lottery was his idea.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: You don't understand. From the moment it began, the dragon was tame. The kingdom prospered.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: And only a few had to be sacrificed.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Yes, that's true. Isn't it better that a few should die that many might live?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Depends on who does the dying.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Oh, but we all take our chances. My father is a just man. My name is entered on the lists, along with every other young --

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Virgin?

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Maiden.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: If you say so.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: I've participated in every drawing since I came of age.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: It's true. You don't believe me. You think I'm lying. Well I'm not.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I heard a rumor. Families with money, that sort of thing.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Don't listen to rumors. They're lies. I have to go now.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Wait -- how long do I have to stay in here?

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Until we know. Not long. Goodbye. Vale. Dormi bene.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: That's enough. Let's not be greedy here.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Now then: I, Casiodorus Rex do hereby command thou base metal to change thy essence and become gold.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Father?

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Not now. Tyrian, remove all but one bar. We'll try it one at a time.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Father: did you know that some families have paid bribes to stay out of the lottery?

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Nonsense. By the power of this amulet, justly wielded by my hand in accordance with the laws of Urland, now lead be thou gold.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: I'm burned! What devilish thing is this?

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Have you ever kept my name off the lottery list?

Speaker: king
Dialogue: That'll be all, Tyrian. You may withdraw.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Now, my dear, what's troubling you?

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Answer my question: am I not exposed to the same risk as every other man's daughter?

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Your father loves you very much.

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: It's true! What have you done to me!?

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Who fills your head with such ideas?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: You little meddler! It's alive!

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Close the main gate! Quick!

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: There! Stop him!

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Get him! Stab the horse!

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Tyrian! Tyrian!

Speaker: king
Dialogue: So much for your magic! So much for your sorcery!

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: Listen to me, my brethren. The moment of our fear is the moment of our triumph. This is a sign from God. Follow me, and our faith will send this creature straight to hell.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: You call yourselves Christians?

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want. Thou makest me to lie down in green pastures. Thy rod and staff they comfort me...

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: ...for Thine is the kingdom and the power and the glory forever -- amen.

Speaker: brother jacopus
Dialogue: Unclean beast, get thee down! Be thou consumed by the fires that made you!

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Get away, you little bastard. We've had enough help from you.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: This is your doing!

Speaker: burlies
Dialogue: Get him! He's back!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Greil -- help!

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: May the Lord forgive you for what you have done.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: It's me. Are you hurt?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Where have you been? Doesn't matter -- listen: Quick! Make it rain. That'll put the fire out.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Then get the animals back. They're all running loose. There's people been hurt. Stop their pain. You can cure them. And we'll need food...

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I can't do it.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: What? Why not?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I just can't.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: But you're a sorcerer.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I'm no sorcerer. Whatever power I might have had, it's gone.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: It can't be!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I know: I'm an imposter. A fraud. A fake. I'm sorry...

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You're sorry?! Listen to that! The damn thing is loose, we're all on fire and you're sorry!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You didn't have the faintest idea what you were doing, did you? You're a fool -- and I'm a bigger one for bringing you here.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I don't want you in this house. Get out.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Where is he?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Not here. I can't help you.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You too?

Speaker: malkin
Dialogue: Damn right.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: As the proud new father of an eligible daughter who was some-how overlooked all these years, it may interest you to know that the King has called for a new lottery.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: But it's months til the solstice.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: In view of what's happened, we all know what's required.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I've never taken part in your cursed lottery, and I'll have nothing to do with it now.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: You were very clever. But she'll take part, like all the rest. No exceptions.

Speaker: henchman
Dialogue: Nothing. If he was here, he's gone now.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: All right. I know what you want. How much?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Are you offering me a bribe?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Don't waste your time.  You could never afford it.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Smith -- have you ever forged a weapon?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: These are your sharpest?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Even Tyrian carries one of these.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: It's sharp -- but it's not sharp enough.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Not sharp enough for what?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: For what I'm going to do with it.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Nothing's that sharp.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: The best I ever made.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: It's beautiful.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Don't do that!  -- but not the nerve to use it.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I'm thankful for that.  No man should choose a senseless death.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: If it's me you're worried about, don't. So my name has been entered, what of it? There are hundreds of girls. My name just won't be drawn. I know it won't.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Valerian, this isn't just for your sake.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I don't care. It doesn't matter. What you want to kill isn't flesh and blood.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Oh, it'll bleed, all right.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: How do you know? No one's so much as even scratched it.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I'll need the amulet.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Look at her. The Princess.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I know. We've met.

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: People of Urland: whereas the peace of the kingdom has been disrupted by the mischief of an interloper; and whereas this interloper being fled; now therefore, his majesty the King hereby proclaims the sum of thirty ducats to be paid to anyone producing the miscreant Galen Bradwardyn, fraud enchanter, to our satisfaction.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Stir the tiles! Stir the tiles!

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Bare the arm! Bare the arm!

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Draw the name! Draw the name!

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: Now, my countrymen, hear me: behold, for I am chosen. I shall die that many may live. I shall lay down my life for family and fellows. I shall go to my grave for the love of our King and his wise policy. And my name is --

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: The name! The name!

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Read the name.

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: The name is: Princess Elspeth Ulfilas, filia regis.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: That's not the name. It's been misread.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: There's no mistake! The name's been chosen -- let it stand!

Speaker: king
Dialogue: No, the good Horsrik has misspoke himself.  In fairness to this individual, whose name I can't make out, we'll destroy this tile.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: No! What better name than your own kin? At last we see justice done!

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Silence! We will have a new choosing. I will draw the name myself.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Let it stand! Let it stand!

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: The name is as you heard it and as Horsrik read it: Elspeth.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: The lottery is invalid. Another and another. What treachery is this?

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Hear me, good people! It is true, that my name appears on many of the lots. This does not falsify the drawing, it certifies it! I have learned that my name has been kept from jeopardy in all the drawings in the past. So I have put my name among the rest many times -- once for each risk that, over the years, you took and I did not.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Don't go to all that trouble.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I'm unarmed. If you want a fight, at least give me a weapon.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: I think not!

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Stop! Don't harm him.  And you -- don't run away... please...

Speaker: king
Dialogue: That's still going to happen.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Sire!

Speaker: king
Dialogue: He shall have it.  It's my daughter. Save her, I beg you.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Holy of holies -- he did not die in vain. Can you hear me, brothers?

Speaker: malkin
Dialogue: We hear you, Greil.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Well and good, but I'm Greil no longer. Call me Gregorius, after the Bishop of Rome.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: I saw him die. Like Our Lord Jesus on the cross he was, scourged by evil. But he showed no fear. Such is the power of the Holy Ghost.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Of what avail is magic? The old gods died with our daughters. From whence comest my help? My help comest from the Lord!

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Good and hot.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Don't bother. That's not the kind of fire we need.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Nunc, per Potestatem Hermeticum -- ex flammis, ferrum sangrinarium!

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: An edge like no other on this earth.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Well done, Simon. Thank you.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I'll say goodbye to Valerian for you. I'm sorry she's not here, but you know how she is.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Fare thee well.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Galen.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: It's a shield. I made it. Might keep the fire off you. Might not. You know, you're an idiot. You're going to die tonight. You'll be ripped limb from limb. This is the last time I'll ever speak to you.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Another thing. That thing isn't alone up there. There's little ones. Young, I think. I don't know how many.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Hatchlings. They'll have to be killed too. Anything else?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You're in love, aren't you?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: That's all right. I understand. She's very beautiful, very brave.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Who is? What do you mean?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Your Princess. But I don't care. It doesn't change the way I feel.  Listen to me, Galen Bradwardyn, sorcerer's apprentice; you're going to be dead, the dragon will be worse than ever, there will be more lotteries, and I'm not a boy any more.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: And you'll be eligible because --

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Because I'm still a virgin, and I want you to do something about it.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I am in love. But not with the Princess.

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: Now be it known throughout the kingdom, that the Princess, having been chosen by a deed of fortune and destiny --

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: No fire, I beg you.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Be gone!

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: I declare these proceedings duly ordained...

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: I knew I'd find you here. Well, I'm not as sentimental as some. The kingdom, every one of us, need this sacrifice. If you intend to interfere, you'll have to kill me.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I've got plenty of reasons to kill you that have nothing to do with this sacrifice.

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: Most impressive. Can you use it?

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Let it be! Please! Tyrian is right -- it's our only hope!

Speaker: elspeth
Dialogue: Tyrian -- both of you -- run! Flee! It's coming!

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: In a trice! This is no swords-man.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Run! Get out of here!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No! Stop! What are you doing?

Speaker: tyrian
Dialogue: You've failed, my friend, and I thank the gods for it. Come out from behind that post.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Elspeth!

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Still alive.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You know what we have to do.  We have to leave Urland.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Not because of what happened. I brought you here -- it didn't work -- now I'm taking you away. Do you understand?  Galen?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: She's right. What kind of a life could you have here? It's too late for me, but you're young enough.  You know what I think? Magic is dying out, fading from the world. But that makes me happy. That means the dragon will be dying too.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Nothing. I was just thinking -- poor Hodge.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: How's your leg?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Hurts. That thing was small, but its teeth were sharp.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: At least you killed it. You got all the young.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: But the big one's alive. Somewhere down in that burning lake.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Don't think about it. You had your fight, and you're still here. That's more than anyone else can say. Let's think about what lies ahead.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: You old trickster! The burning water! The lake of fire!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Galen, what are you saying?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: He had it planned. He knew this was going to happen.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Who did? What happened?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: We've got to go back, I want to talk to him!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: The Church is mother to us all. Not just one lonely orphan who has lost his way, not just a few, but all of us that believeth in Him. When enough voices come together in prayer, He shall hear, we shall live and the beast shall die.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Galen, stop! Please, I beg you!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Stop! I won't let you kill yourself.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: He couldn't walk -- he knew he couldn't make the journey. So he had us make the journey for him! Don't you see?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: All right, all right. You're going in there, I'm going too.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: What? Why? No you're not, this is my job. Absolutely not.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: I'm not afraid. And you're not going to stop me. After all -- I've been a man longer than you have.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Stay close.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Never mind. Come on.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: All right. Wait here.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Galen? Galen? Where are you?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Ex favilla, vita nova!

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Be calm. He watcheth over us! And this is His sign! Let us pray! Our Father who art in heaven...

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Ulrich! Magister! Over here! I can see you! Over here!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Not so loud. I'm not deaf, you know.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Sic redit magus ex terra mortis.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Wonder of wonders -- you're back! I thank the powers that made me!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Glad to see you, too. You didn't bring along anything to eat, by any chance?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Food?

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: No? Oh well, no time anyway.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Come along. There's much to be done.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Wait, I have something to tell you.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: It can wait.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No it can't. Listen: I thought I was a sorcerer -- but I wasn't. I thought I had power -- but I didn't. I thought I was you -- but I'm not.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Well said. Now hurry.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Draco draconis...

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Galen!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Where's my amulet? Give it to me, please.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Be quick!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Come close to me.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Don't be afraid. You have served me with great courage. Now you must show me you have even more.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Anything!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: You must destroy the amulet, and me along with it.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: You brought me from the flames, you must send me back.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: When the time comes, you'll understand. Here.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: I know what you're thinking. You have learned much and done well. Don't worry, you won't need it any more.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Make haste, brother.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Now be thou baptized in the name of the Father, Son and Holy Ghost. May the Lord our God light our way.

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Nimbus! Tempestas! Fulmen!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Here. Do as he said. Smash it.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Not if it means killing him.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You heard what he said.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No! You can't!

Speaker: ulrich
Dialogue: Galen!

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Let us pray.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: We thank thee, Lord, for this divine deliverance. Verily is thy presence amongst us, fully manifest in this, thy great work.

Speaker: greil
Dialogue: Arise, children of the Lord and forsake evermore the pagan mysteries. Rejoice in the true power of the Christian God!

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: All hail Casiodorus Rex -- Dragon slayer!

Speaker: horsrik
Dialogue: Hail and praise be!

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You want to rest?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No. I'm fine.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: You miss Ulricn.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: And the amulet.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: That too.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Not me. I'm glad it's gone. I'm glad you did what you did.  You may not be a sorcerer, Galen, but I love you anyway. I don't regret anything that happened. I just wish --

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: -- that we had a horse.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: A horse.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Did you...!?

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: No. It must have been wandering loose. Or wild.

Speaker: valerian
Dialogue: Wait a minute. I just wished for a horse and here it is.

Speaker: galen
Dialogue: You don't want to wish it gone, do you?
